newsitem.title: ITALY: No cabinet action today on Italy's Stet.
newsitem.headline: No cabinet action today on Italy's Stet.

text.p: A meeting of the Italian cabinet that was taking place on Friday will not discuss measures to transfer telecom holding Stet to the Treasury, a government source said.

Political sources said previously that the meeting, which began at 0900 GMT, could discuss relevant measures after the government suffered a surprise parliamentary defeat on the transfer plan on Wednesday night.
"Nothing is being done about Stet" at the cabinet meeting, the source said.
La Repubblica newspaper quoted cabinet undersecretary Enrico Micheli as saying measures would be considered at a forthcoming meeting of ministers.
"The defeat of the plan leaves only some collateral aspects uncovered. These will be dealt with by an ad hoc provision...which could be approved at a forthcoming cabinet meeting," Micheli said.
The Treasury said last month it would pay at least 14.53 trillion lire to state holding IRI to take over its controlling stake in Stet ahead of its planned privatisation.
The government narrowly lost the vote in the lower house of parliament on the transfer by 230 to 234 with 26 abstentions.

The Treasury wants full control of Stet because it fears foot-dragging by IRI managers will hold up its privatisation. The move also allows the government to fulfil a commitment to slash IRI's huge debt.
Prime Minister Romano Prodi said on Thursday that the defeat would not affect the government's privatisation programme but acknowledged that it was a "political alarm signal".
The hardline party Communist Refoundation, which ensures the government's majority in parliament, abstained on the vote, contributing to the defeat and raising strains in the alliance.
